If you cultivate summer vegetables like snap beans, cucumbers or summer squash after the season, they can actually grow until the winter arrives. When temperatures remain above 20 degrees, you will find many vegetables that can grow well. You will additionally find some other vegetables that will be finished when a tiny bit of frost comes. By using lots of mulch, the edible section of tuber plants can be saved, even when the tops are killed by a freeze.

In order to beat the frost, you need vegetables with the shortest growing time for fall gardening, so they can be harvested in time. You should search for seeds that can quickly develop or bear fruit earlier in a season. If you want to use them, I suggest you get them before the summer starts since they tend to run out toward the end of summer. If you are able to save them in a cool dry place, then they ought to be ready for you when you need them. You should be up on the conditions locally to know when to plant. The Farmer's Almanac can generally inform you when the first hard frost will hit, so that will tell you when to start your fall garden. The timing of your planting is essential so that you can have vegetables ready before the weather turns on you.

If you want to get the dirt ready, you should get rid of crops and weeds. Unless you make this happen, disease and bacteria may spread throughout your garden. It is recommended that you put in a several inches of compost or mulch over the area to improve the nutrient content of your soil. If you did a lot of fertilizing during the spring, you may not need to add very much. You will be completely ready for planting, once you till the top layer of soil, wet it down and let it set for 12 to 24 hours. You will discover that frosts may come rarely for many years but will come suddenly and could potentially ruin your hard work.

You may determine that having a fall garden is not worth the effort. However if you take a chance, you will find that the veggies you produce will be superior than what you tasted in spring.
